text: Key Events in Ukraine (late2025 snapshot)1. Diplomatic stalemate      Moscow says Kiev refuses 24/7 talks or workinggroup formats; Kiev says Russia answers every peace probe with missiles.      Istanbulformat meetings continue, but only on narrow humanitarian issues (exchanges, bodies). Political items remain frozen.2. Escalating terror against civilians      14 Sep: 21 killed (4 children) in Kyiv morning strike; EU & UK missions damaged.      9 Sep: Glide bomb on pension queue in Yarova, Donetsk – 21 dead.      28 Sep: 12hour night assault on Kyiv – 600 drones + 48 missiles, ≥ 4 civilians killed (incl. 12yrold girl).      Nationwide pattern: > 3 500 drones, 190 missiles, 2 500 glide bombs launched by Russia in September alone; energy grid repeatedly hit.3. Frontline & deepstrike exchanges      Ukraine hits Russian oil infrastructure (Saratov, Afipsky, Kuybyshevskyi, Chuvashia pump station) and airfields as far as Murmansk and Amur; US envoy Kellogg warns this raises risk to nucleartriad level.      Russia advances grind in Donbas (Lyman axis) while stepping up air campaign.4. Security incidents beyond Ukraine      Drones over Polish & Romanian airspace (≥ 19 objects); brief Polish airspace closure.      Mystery drones above 6 Danish and Norwegian airports; NATO frigates & ISR surge into Baltic.      Italian court okays extradition to Germany of Ukrainian national over 2022 NordStream sabotage; Kiev denies state role.5. Western support metrics      EU: €169 bn total aid since 2022, €63 bn military; 2025 deliveries already a record €25 bn.      Patriot batteries pledged at NATO July summit; one battery quietly delivered by Israel (operational one month).      Germany & Sweden publicly press US for 19th sanctions package; Trump says US will sanction only after every NATO state ends Russian energy purchases—i.e., delayed.6. Ideational / institutional fronts      Lavrov at UN GA: NATO & EU have declared real war on Russia through Ukraine.      IPC (International Paralympic Committee) lifts blanket ban on Russia & Belarus; Ukraine protests.      Moldova votes under alleged Russian interference; outcome watched as EUvsRussia barometer.7. Planning for the day after      NBC reports Pentagon contingency study: US could monitor a demilitarised buffer zone plus thirdcountry (e.g., Saudi, Bangladesh) observers—yet Trump privately pessimistic about nearterm deal. Chance of Peace – Analysis 1. Battlefield calculus   Russia still gains marginal terrain in Donbas and believes sustained aerial coercion can break Ukrainian morale.   Ukraine demonstrates ability to strike deep into Russian strategic rear, raising costs but also escalation risk (nuclear triad references).  Stalemate index: High – neither side faces imminent military collapse. 2. Political will   Kiev: Public narrative centres on restoring pre2014 territory; after civilian bombings, concessions appear politically toxic.   Moscow: Open to talks rhetorically, yet insists on keeping seized land and security guarantees (neutrality, NATO rollback).  Overlap: Virtually zero; compromise seen as defeat by both constituencies. 3. External drivers   United States: Trump oscillates between sanctions threats and summit pageantry; defence establishment plans buffer missions, but no enforcement mechanism is agreed. Congress supports Ukraine but White House signals transactional approach (energyimport conditionality).   Europe: Record military aid, 19th sanctions package in pipeline, but Hungary/Slovakia energy ties slow unanimity.   China: Proclaims neutrality, yet Ukrainian intel traces drone & chip supplies to Russia—Beijing profits from discounted Russian energy and has little incentive to press Moscow.  Bidenera coalition largely intact, but intraWestern frictions over speed and scope of pressure. 4. Escalation traps   Attacks on Russian strategic airfields invoke nucleartaboo rhetoric.   Incidents inside NATO airspace create structural risk of accidental clash.   CrimeanBridgestyle sabotage operations complicate any ceasefire monitoring. 5. Time horizon   Winter approaching: Russia targeting energy grid; Ukraine needs Patriot missiles, not just promises. Humanitarian strain inside Ukraine and refugeehost states will grow, potentially altering cost calculations.   US electoral calendar 2026 already casting shadow; both Moscow and Kiev may postpone big moves until clearer Washington stance. Probability assessment (6–12 mo.)  Negotiated, comprehensive peace: ≤ 10 %   Core demands irreconcilable; trust below zero; domestic politics punish concessions.Frozen or limited ceasefire (e.g., energysecurity truce, BlackSea corridor): ≈ 30 %   Could emerge if battlefield attrition plus refugee/economic strain converges with Trump desire for deal optics. Requires:    – Verifiable moratorium on strikes inside Russia proper.    – Russian pause on energygrid attacks.    – Thirdparty troops physically interposed.  Still fragile; either side could spoil.Continuation of highintensity war (most likely): ≈ 60 %   Material and political conditions favour ongoing violence: no coercion deficit on either side, ample external supply lines, permissive domestic opinion, profitable sanctionscircumvention channels. Net Judgement  Peace is imaginable only as a suboptimal, weaponsonstandby pause, not as a settlement. The structural incentives still reward fighting, and the informational space is too poisoned for reciprocal compromise. Absent either a strategic shock (leadership change in Moscow or Kiev) or a drastic external leverage shift (full USEurope embargo plus enforceable security guarantees), Ukraine’s war is more likely to enter its fourth calendar year than to end through diplomacy this year.
